coredata.dc:title: Synergistic effects of ozone/peroxymonosulfate for isothiazolinone biocides degradation: Kinetics, synergistic performance and influencing factors
coredata.dc:creator: Yang, Zheng-Wei
Wang, Wen-Long
Lee, Min-Yong
Wu, Qian-Yuan
Guan, Yun-Tao
coredata.dc:description:
Synergistic effects of ozone (O3) and peroxymonosulfate (PMS, HSO5 −) for isothiazolinone biocides degradation was studied. The synergistic ozonation process (O3/PMS) increased the efficiency of methyl-isothiazolinone (MIT) and chloro-methyl-isothiazolinone (CMIT) degradation to 91.0% and 81.8%, respectively, within 90 s at pH 7.0. This is 30.6% and 62.5% higher than the corresponding ozonation efficiency, respectively. Total radical formation value (R ct,
R) for the O3/PMS process was 24.6 times that of ozonation alone. Calculated second-order rate constants for the reactions between isothiazolinone biocides and
Image 1 (k SO4
-,MIT and k SO4
-,CMIT) were 8.15 × 109 and 4.49 × 109 M−1 s−1, respectively. Relative contributions of O3, hydroxyl radical (OH) and
Image 1 oxidation to MIT and CMIT removal were estimated, which were 15%, 45%, and 40% for O3, OH and
Image 1 oxidation to MIT, and 1%, 67%, and 32% for O3, OH and
Image 1 oxidation to CMIT at pH 7.0, respectively. Factors influencing the O3/PMS process, namely the solution pH, chloride ions (Cl−), and bicarbonate (HCO3 −), were evaluated. Increasing the solution pH markedly accelerated O3 decay and OH and
Image 1 formation, thus weakening the relative contribution of O3 oxidation while enhancing that of OH and
Image 1 . Cl− had a negligible effect on MIT and CMIT degradation. Under the dual effect of bicarbonate (HCO3 −) as inhibitor and promoter, low concentrations (1–2 mM) of bicarbonate weakly promoted MIT and CMIT degradation, while high concentrations (10–20 mM) induced strong inhibition. Lastly, oxidation performance of O3 and O3/PMS processes for MIT and CMIT degradation in different water matrices was compared.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Synergistic effects of ozone (O3) and peroxymonosulfate (PMS, HSO5 −) for isothiazolinone biocides degradation was studied. The synergistic ozonation process (O3/PMS) increased the efficiency of methyl-isothiazolinone (MIT) and chloro-methyl-isothiazolinone (CMIT) degradation to 91.0% and 81.8%, respectively, within 90 s at pH 7.0. This is 30.6% and 62.5% higher than the corresponding ozonation efficiency, respectively. Total radical formation value (R ct,
R) for the O3/PMS process was 24.6 times that of ozonation alone. Calculated second-order rate constants for the reactions between isothiazolinone biocides and
Image 1 (k SO4
-,MIT and k SO4
-,CMIT) were 8.15 × 109 and 4.49 × 109 M−1 s−1, respectively. Relative contributions of O3, hydroxyl radical (OH) and
Image 1 oxidation to MIT and CMIT removal were estimated, which were 15%, 45%, and 40% for O3, OH and
Image 1 oxidation to MIT, and 1%, 67%, and 32% for O3, OH and
Image 1 oxidation to CMIT at pH 7.0, respectively. Factors influencing the O3/PMS process, namely the solution pH, chloride ions (Cl−), and bicarbonate (HCO3 −), were evaluated. Increasing the solution pH markedly accelerated O3 decay and OH and
Image 1 formation, thus weakening the relative contribution of O3 oxidation while enhancing that of OH and
Image 1 . Cl− had a negligible effect on MIT and CMIT degradation. Under the dual effect of bicarbonate (HCO3 −) as inhibitor and promoter, low concentrations (1–2 mM) of bicarbonate weakly promoted MIT and CMIT degradation, while high concentrations (10–20 mM) induced strong inhibition. Lastly, oxidation performance of O3 and O3/PMS processes for MIT and CMIT degradation in different water matrices was compared.

ce:section.ce:para: Shortage of water resources and degradation of water quality caused by pollution are worldwide problems. For example, a study showed that more than four billion people periodically endure severe water shortages (Mekonnen and Hoekstra, 2016). Water reuse and recycling are effective measures to alleviate water shortage and improve the water environment. They have been widely applied, for example, in Singapore, Canada, and Australia (Lee and Tan, 2016; Radcliffe and Page, 2020; Van Rossum, 2020).

However, in recent years, emerging pollutants (EPs) have been found both in natural water and municipal wastewater. EPs are detrimental to water reuse because of their low concentration, high toxicity, and refractory (Zhou et al., 2019). Among EPs, isothiazolinone biocides, such as methyl-isothiazolinone (MIT) and chloro-methyl-isothiazolinone (CMIT) show high bactericidal activity and are widely used in daily necessities (e.g., cosmetics, disinfectants) and industrial production (e.g., reverse osmosis systems and industrial water cycle), because they can spread through bacterial cell membranes and fungal cell walls (Garcia-Hidalgo et al., 2018; Silva et al., 2020). However, isothiazolinone biocides show high toxicity to aquatic organisms once they flow into municipal wastewater and natural water. For example, MIT can severely damage the photosynthetic system of algae and inhibit the production of photosynthetic oxygen (Wang et al., 2018). Isothiazolinone biocides also have lethal effects on zebrafish, rainbow trout and daphnia magna, with the median lethal concentrations of 0.072–2 mg/L (Capkin et al., 2017; Li et al., 2016b). What's more, isothiazolinone biocides have strong toxic effects on human body. Many studies have shown that isothiazolinone biocides can cause allergic dermatitis, damage the human respiratory system and the immune system of mammals (Devos et al., 2015; Lee et al., 2019; Schwensen et al., 2017).

With the increased use of disinfectants during the COVID-19 pandemic, biocides have become a significant secondary health risk (Subpiramaniyam, 2021). Unfortunately, isothiazolinone biocides cannot be eliminated efficiently in traditional biological treatment, because they can inhibit the activated sludge process (Liu et al., 2012). Previous studies have shown that isothiazolinone biocides were widely existed in wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) and their receiving water bodies. For example, the concentration of isothiazolinone biocides was 0.2–0.9 μg/L in WWTPs influents of Paris conurbation, and the average MIT concentration in the effluents was 0.15 μg/L (Paijens et al., 2021). Similarly, 19 biocides were universally detected in 10 WWTPs influents in South China, and the average concentrations of isothiazolinone biocides in the receiving water were close to 0.4 μg/L due to the effluent discharge (Liu et al., 2017). Therefore, it is important to study the efficient degradation process of isothiazolinone biocides for human and environmental health.

Ozone (O3) is widely applied to decolorization, disinfection, and elimination of refractory micropollutants because of its strong oxidizing capacity (Cardoso et al., 2016; Ding et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2019). Ozonation is also highly effective in degrading isothiazolinone biocides (Huang et al., 2021; Li et al., 2016b). During ozonation, there are two main oxidation pathways, one is the direct oxidation by molecule O3 and the other is the indirect oxidation by hydroxyl radical (OH) (Bennett, 2006). The redox potential of O3 and OH are 2.07 and 2.8 V, respectively, and O3 targets electron-rich moieties selectively, while OH reacts with pollutants at high reaction rate constants of 109–1010 M−1 s−1 non-selectively (von Sonntag and von Gunten, 2012). Limitations of traditional ozonation are an insufficient ozonation capacity, low O3 utilization efficiency and limited radical formation. Therefore, synergistic ozonation processes, such as O3/H2O2, O3/NH2OH, or O3/NH2Cl, have been developed to enhance radical yield and refractory micropollutants degradation (Huang et al., 2021; Lee et al., 2017; Yang et al., 2016).

The sulfate radical (
Image 1 ) has recently received more attention because of its redox potential as high as 2.5–3.1 V and high values of near-diffusion-limited reaction rates for most organic matter (Deniere et al., 2018).
Image 1 is usually formed by activating peroxymonosulfate (PMS, HSO5 −) and perdisulfate (PDS, S2O8 2−) with heat, UV radiation or transition metal (Guan et al., 2013; Shad et al., 2020). Yang et al. (2015) found that PMS can also be activated by O3 to generate OH and
Image 1 simultaneously at radical yields of 0.43 and 0.45, respectively (Eqs. (1)–(9)). Whereas, PDS cannot directly react with O3 because that the sulfonic groups bridged by peroxy group (O–O) in PDS are O3-resistant (von Sonntag and von Gunten, 2012; Yang et al., 2015). Combined O3 and PMS can effectively degrade refractory micropollutants like para-chlorobenzoic acid (pCBA) and ibuprofen (IBP) (Cong et al., 2015; Yuan et al., 2017). Among reported synergistic ozonation, O3/PMS showed considerably higher radical yields than ozonation and O3/H2O2 (Wu et al., 2021). Thus, O3/PMS is expected to achieve rapid and efficient performance for the elimination of isothiazolinone biocides, which has not been reported in previous investigations.

In this work, the oxidation capacity and radical formation characteristics of O3/PMS for MIT and CMIT degradation are investigated. Second-order rate constants of isothiazolinone biocides reaction with
Image 1 (k SO4
-,MIT and k SO4
-,CMIT) are determined by second-order kinetics. Oxidation contributions of O3, OH, and
Image 1 are evaluated. Additionally, the effect of water quality parameters (solution pH, chloride ions, bicarbonate) is systematically assessed. Finally, performance of the O3 and O3/PMS processes in different water matrices is compared.

MIT and CMIT were obtained from ANPEL (Shanghai, China). PMS was purchased from 3A Chemicals (Shanghai, China). Sodium PDS and nitrobenzene (NB) were obtained from Energy (Shanghai, China). Atrazine (ATZ) was obtained from J&K (Beijing, China). Formic acid was obtained from Aladdin Bio-Tech (Shanghai, China). Ascorbic acid was obtained from Macklin Bio-Tech (Shanghai, China). Suwannee River Natural Organic Matter (SRNOM) 2R101N was purchased from the International Humic Substances Society (IHSS). SRNOM stock solution was prepared by dissolving SRNOM in ultrapure water and filtering through 0.45 μm membrane. Other chemical reagents were of analytical grade, such as NaH2PO4, Na2HPO4, NaOH, NaHCO3, and NaCl. All aqueous solutions were prepared from ultrapure water (UPW) prepared with a Milli-Q system (Millipore, Massachusetts, USA).
Water quality parameters of a secondary effluent sample collected from a WWTP (Shenzhen, China) are listed in Table S1.

O3 was prepared by an ozone generator (NLO-25, Newland Entech Co., Fujian, China). O3 was bubbled into ultrapure water to obtain the O3 stock solution. The isothiazolinone biocides degradation experiments were carried out in 100 mL glass conical flasks. A specific volume of O3 stock solution was injected into a mixture containing MIT, CMIT, and PMS at pre-defined concentrations. The final concentrations of MIT and CMIT were 1 mg L−1. The solution pH was controlled by 5 mM phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), which was composed of NaH2PO4 and Na2HPO4. Samples were withdrawn at specified time-intervals and analyzed for the concentrations of MIT, CMIT, and O3. ATZ and NB were used as probe compounds to evaluate the formation of OH and
Image 1 . The residual O3 was quenched by ascorbic acid when the samples were used for analysis for MIT and CMIT.

Concentrations of MIT, CMIT, ATZ, and NB were determined by HPLC, which coupled with a PDA detector (Shimadzu, Japan). Chromatographic separations were achieved using a C18 column (length: 250 mm, internal diameter: 4.2 mm, particle size: 5 μm, ANPEL Laboratory Technologies, Shanghai, China). Injection volume was 20 μL. The organic mobile phase was methanol while the inorganic mobile phase was UPW containing 0.1% formic acid. The volume ratio of organic and inorganic mobile phase was 45:55. The total flow rate was 1 mL min−1. MIT, CMIT, ATZ, and NB were detected at λ = 273, λ = 273, λ = 221, and λ = 262 nm, respectively.
Residual O3 concentrations in the samples were measured by potassium indigo trisulfonate colorimetry (Wang et al., 2019).

All experiments were repeated two or more times independently. All data were analyzed by Microsoft Excel 2019 (Redmond, WA., USA) and all figures were prepared by OriginPro 2018 (Northampton, MA, USA). The error bars were used to represent the standard deviation, and the upper edge represented a higher value while the lower edge represented a lower value. The least square method was used for linear fitting.

The degradation of MIT and CMIT by ozonation alone, PMS alone, PDS alone, O3/PMS, and O3/PDS at pH 7.0 was compared, as shown in Fig. 1 . The elimination efficiency of MIT increased from 60.3% for ozonation alone to 91.0% for O3/PMS within a reaction time of 90 s. CMIT degradation efficiency increased from 19.3% to 81.8% in the same conditions. Combining O3 and PDS did not increase the MIT and CMIT degradation efficiency. This suggested that PDS was not activated by O3, which was similar to previous studies (Qin et al., 2020; Yang et al., 2015; Yuan et al., 2017).

The O3 decay in ozonation and O3/PMS processes was shown in Fig. S1. The addition of PMS accelerates O3 decay and promotes the formation of OH and
Image 1 , resulting promotion influence on radical-oxidation and inhibition influence on O3-oxidation (Wu et al., 2021; Yang et al., 2015). Thus, the synergistic performance on MIT and CMIT degradation in O3/PMS was different due to their different O3-reactivity properties. MIT is moderately O3-reactive while CMIT is O3-resistant. The second-order rate constant of the reaction between MIT and O3 (k O3,MIT) is 200.4 M−1 s−1, and the corresponding value between CMIT and O3 (k O3,CMIT) is 9.2 M−1 s−1 (Wang et al., 2019). As a result, the enhancement of CMIT degradation in O3/PMS was more prominent than that of MIT. This will be discussed in more detail below.

Both OH and
Image 1 were formed in the O3/PMS process. In this case, MIT and CMIT degradation can be analyzed by integrating over the possible oxidation pathways (Eqs. (10)–(13)) and applying a linear fit with O3 exposure (∫[O3]dt) as a function (Elovitz and von Gunten, 1999).

- can be quantified with radical probes. NB reacts primarily with OH (k
OH,NB = 3.9 × 109 M−1 s−1) but only weakly with

-,NB < 106 M−1 s−1) and hardly with O3 (k O3,NB = 0.09 M−1 s−1). ATZ reacts mostly with OH (k
OH,ATZ = 2.6 × 109 M−1 s−1) and

-,ATZ = 2.6 × 109 M−1 s−1) but very weakly with O3 (k O3,ATZ = 6 M−1 s−1)(Mao et al., 2020; Yang et al., 2015). Calculated R ct,
OH and R ct,SO4
- were 9.13 × 10−8 and 6.69 × 10−8 for the O3/PMS process, while R ct,
OH for ozonation alone was 6.44 × 10−9, as shown in Table S2 and Fig. S2. This means that the total R ct,
R in O3/PMS was 24.6 times that of ozonation alone. Therefore, the presence of PMS promoted OH and
Image 1 formation in O3/PMS and strengthened the radical oxidation pathway for micropollutant degradation. This finding illustrates the benefits of O3/PMS synergies for O3-resistant micropollutant degradation.

Using secondary reaction kinetics, we calculated second-order rate constants of 8.15 × 109 M−1 s−1 for the reaction between MIT and
Image 1 (k SO4
-, MIT) and 4.49 × 109 M−1 s−1 for the reaction between CMIT and O4
− (k SO4
-,CMIT), as the second-order rate constants for MIT and CMIT reactions with O3 and OH have been determined in previous study (Wang et al., 2019). The high reactivity of
Image 1 with isothiazolinone biocides implies that
Image 1 can rapidly oxidize MIT and CMIT. A possible reaction mechanism for
Image 1 with MIT or CMIT could be explained by the electrophilicity of
Image 1 , reacting preferentially with electron-rich sulfur atoms to form sulfone products (Lee et al., 2020; Li et al., 2016a).

According to Eq. (11), the fractions of isothiazolinone biocides reacting with O3, OH and
Image 1 can be determined by Eqs. (14)–(16), which further enabled the estimation of the relative contributions of oxidation by O3, OH, and
Image 1 to MIT and CMIT elimination (Table S2 and Fig. 2 ).

For ozonation alone in PBS at pH 7.0, contributions of O3 and OH oxidation to MIT degradation (f O3,MIT and f
OH,MIT) were 82% and 18%, respectively. For CMIT degradation, contributions (f O3,CMIT and f
OH,CMIT) were 17% and 83%, respectively. Therefore, during ozonation, O3 oxidation was the main pathway for MIT degradation while OH oxidation contributed the most to CMIT degradation. During the O3/PMS process (also in PBS at pH 7.0), calculated contributions were 15%, 45%, and 40% for f O3,MIT, f
OH,MIT, and f SO4
-,MIT, and 1%, 67%, and 32% for f O3,CMIT, f
OH,CMIT, and f SO4
-,CMIT, respectively. These results show that, because of the synergistic effect of PMS and O3, radical oxidation (by OH and
Image 1 ) was enhanced relative to O3 oxidation and played a more important role in MIT and CMIT degradation.

Effects of solution pH in the O3/PMS process are shown in Fig. 3 . When the solution pH increased from 5.0 to 7.5, degradation efficiency increased from 53.8% for MIT and 10.6% for CMIT to 100% for both within 60 s; the observed MIT degradation rate (k obs, MIT) increased by 26.7 times, from 299.9 to 8011.3 M−1 s−1, and the observed CMIT removal rate (k obs, CMIT) increased by 282.3 times, from 26.1 to 7368.7 M−1 s−1.

PMS dissociation, O3 consumption, and radical formation were significantly affected by solution pH (von Sonntag and von Gunten, 2012; Yang et al., 2015). For a pK a value of 9.4, PMS was found in different forms depending on the pH. Generally, a solution with higher pH contains a higher fraction of deprotonated oxidants (SO5 2−), accelerating O3 consumption (Rani et al., 2009; Wu et al., 2019). When pH increased from 5.0 to 7.5, the O3 decay rate increased from 2.81 × 10−3 to 4.42 × 10−2 s−1 and O3 exposure decreased from 7.0 to 0.9 mM s (Fig. S3 and Table S2). The synergistic reaction of O3 with deprotonated PMS enhanced radical formation (Liu et al., 2021; Yuan et al., 2017). By analyzing the (logarithmic) dependence of probe compounds degradation on O3 exposure, we calculated that R ct,
OH increased from 2.53 × 10−9 to 8.57 × 10−7 and R ct,SO4
- from 1.49 × 10−9 to 6.15 × 10−7 when pH increased from 5.0 to 7.5 (Table S2). However, changes in the solution pH did not affect the formation ratio of OH and
Image 1 . R ct,
OH/R ct,SO4
- values remained comparable (1.37–1.46) when pH increased from 6.5 to 7.5. This indicated that the reaction between O3 and SO5 2− was predominant compared with the reaction between O3 and OH− under the circumneutral condition. Yang et al. (2015) reported the similar results that the values of R ct,
OH increased from 1.2 × 10−8 to 8.5 × 10−8 and R ct,SO4
- from 1.4 × 10−8 to 9.5 × 10−8 when pH increased from 7.0 to 8.0, while the ratio of R ct,
OH/R ct,SO4
- remained almost unchanged.

Lastly, effects of solution pH on the oxidation contributions of O3, OH and
Image 1 were also investigated. An increase of the solution pH induced that O3 exposure decreased and radical exposure increased, thereby weakening O3 oxidation while enhancing OH and
Image 1 oxidation (Fig. 4 ). For MIT degradation, an increase of solution pH from 5.0 to 7.5 caused the O3 oxidation contribution to decrease from 87% to 2%, while the contribution of OH oxidation increased from 7% to 52% and that of
Image 1 from 5% to 46%. For CMIT degradation, the O3 oxidation contribution was 27% at pH 5.0, while combined contributions of OH and
Image 1 oxidation represented almost 100% at pH > 6, because CMIT is O3-resistant.

Chloride ions (Cl−), abundant in natural water, are common inorganic ions. Effects of Cl− on isothiazolinone biocides degradation were investigated in PBS at pH 7.0, as shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 . The presence of Cl− in relatively low concentration (<10 mM) had a negligible effect (or slightly promotion effect) on MIT and CMIT degradation. When Cl− concentration increased to 20 mM, degradation of MIT and CMIT became slightly inhibited. Liu et al. (2021) obtained similar results in the O3/PMS process that low Cl− concentration slightly increased the removal efficiency while high Cl−concentration slightly decreased the removal efficiency.

The effect of Cl− on O3 decay is negligible at low concentrations (<10 mM) because Cl− cannot be oxidized by O3 (Sotelo et al., 2008). When the concentration of Cl−increased from 0 to 10 mM, the pseudo-ﬁrst order rate constants of O3 decay (k
obs,O3, see in Text S1) and O3 exposure (∫[O3]dt) remained within 1.58–1.66 × 10−2 s−1 and 1.97–2.06 × 10−3 M s, respectively, as shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2. This was consistent with previous research (Yuan et al., 2017).

However, Cl− can influence radical oxidation, promoting OH oxidation while inhibiting
Image 1 oxidation. This is explained by the reaction properties of Cl− with OH and
Image 1 . In a circumneutral solution, Cl− reacts quickly with OH to form ClOH −, which then quickly converts back to OH through the reverse reaction (Eq. (17))(von Gunten, 2003). In contrast, the reaction of Cl− with
Image 1 produces chlorine species with lower reactivity and higher selectivity (Eqs. (18)–(21)) (Lee et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2020). The induced Cl− effect on OH exposure was limited, with exposure values remaining within 9.13–10.5 × 10−8 when the concentration of Cl− increased from 0 to 10 mM. Conversely,
Image 1 exposure decreased in the presence of Cl−. R ct,SO4
- decreased markedly from 6.69 × 10−8 to 9.52 × 10−9 when Cl− concentration increased from 0 to 2 mM (Table S2). Compared with UV/H2O2, Yang et al. (2014) also found that Cl− had a more significant effect on UV/PDS due to that
Image 1 was more easily affected by Cl− than OH. Because of the different effects of Cl− on OH and
Image 1 , relative oxidation contributions of OH and
Image 1 varied during MIT and CMIT degradation (Fig. 6). For example, when Cl− concentration increased from 0 to 2 mM, f
OH, MIT increased from 45% to 71% while f SO4
−, MIT decreased from 39% to 8%.

(18)
(19)

(21)
Cl+Cl→Cl2

At high concentrations (here, 20 mM), Cl− effects became more complex. A group of chlorine radicals, including Cl,
Image 12 , and OCl − started forming (Zhang and Parker, 2018). Concurrently, the effect of Cl− on PMS consumption became more pronounced, delaying O3 decay and slowing radical formation (Lee et al., 2020). As a result, R ct,
OH and R ct,SO4
- decreased to 5.58 × 10−8 and 1.13 × 10−8 , respectively, for a Cl− concentration of 20 mM. Meanwhile, MIT and CMIT degradation was inhibited when Cl− concentration reached 20 mM, and the degradation efficiency for MIT and CMIT decreased by 8.2% and 14.6% compared with that without Cl−, respectively.

Bicarbonate (HCO3 −) is the more abundant species in bicarbonate/carbonate systems under neutral conditions (Farha et al., 2018). We investigated the effects of HCO3 − on MIT and CMIT degradation (Fig. 7 ). At low concentrations (1–2 mM), HCO3 − had a slight promoting effect on MIT and CMIT degradation. However, at higher concentrations (10–20 mM), HCO3 − showed a strong inhibitory effect. MIT and CMIT degradation efficiency increased to 91.5% and 84.5%, respectively, for an HCO3 − concentration of 1 mM, but decreased to 55.2% and 38.6%, respectively, for a concentration of 20 mM. This result is comparable to previous findings (Chen and Wang, 2020; Oguz and Keskinler, 2007).

HCO3 − is a common radical scavenger, generally acting as an inhibitor by capturing OH and
Image 1 to generate carbonate radicals (CO3 •−) and terminate radical chain reactions, thereby increasing O3 lifetime and inhibiting its decay (von Sonntag and von Gunten, 2012). CO3 •− is less oxidizing and attacks electron-rich structures more selectively, with much lower rate constants than those of OH or
Image 1 with most micropollutants (Canonica et al., 2005; Hoigné, 1998). However, in specific conditions, HCO3 − can act as a promoter to accelerate O3 decomposition, for instance, CO3 •− reacts with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to form superoxide that accelerates radical chain reactions via formation of OH(Acero and von Gunten, 2000).

In this study, we found evidence of the dual effect of HCO3 − as inhibitor or promoter. On the one hand, HCO3 − rapidly quenched OH and
Image 1 to generate CO3 •− , with reaction rate constants of 8.5 × 106 and 1.6 × 106 M−1s−1, respectively (Orellana-García et al., 2015). On the other hand, because of its peroxy group (O–O), PMS could react with CO3 •− to form superoxide that, in turn, quickly reacted with O3 to accelerate O3 decomposition and radical formation, like the reaction between CO3 •− and H2O2. During the O3/PMS process, the initial PMS dosage was constant (21 μM). At low HCO3 − concentrations (1–2 mM), it was sufficient to cause PMS to react with CO3 •− and then form radical further, neutralizing the inhibiting effects. At higher HCO3 − concentrations (10–20 mM), the PMS dosage was insufficient. The inhibiting effect of HCO3 − became dominant, inducing a strong decrease of the MIT and CMIT degradation efficiency.

When HCO3 − concentrations increased from 0 to 10 mM, R ct, OH increased from 9.13 × 10−8 to 1.30 × 10−7 and R ct,SO4 increased from 6.69 × 10−8 to 1.71 × 10−7. The O3 decay rate increased from 1.58 × 10−2 to 2.48 × 10−2 s−1 and the instantaneous O3 dose (IOD) (see in Text S1) increased from 0.12 to 1.14 mg/L when HCO3 − concentrations increased from 0 to 20 mM (Fig. S5 and Table S2). At a higher HCO3 − concentration (20 mM), R ct,
OH decreased to 2.99 × 10−8 but R ct,SO4
- still increased (2.55 × 10−7), as shown in Table S2. There are two main reasons for the increase in R ct,SO4
-. First, HCO3 − can directly activate PMS to produce
Image 1 (Jiang et al., 2017). Second, the reaction rate of HCO3 − with OH is higher than with
Image 1 , resulting in preferential quenching of OH. As a result, R ct,
OH/R ct,SO4
-, f
OH,MIT, and f
OH,CMIT decreased while f SO4
−,MIT and f SO4
−,CMIT increased with increasing HCO3 − concentration (Table S2 and Fig. 8 ).

These results show that the initial concentrations of PMS and HCO3 − were important in determining the nature and strength of HCO3 − effects on MIT and CMIT degradation. For carbonate-containing wastewater treatment, the promoting and inhibiting effects of HCO3 − could be neutralized by adjusting the PMS dosage. Therefore, the O3/PMS process could effectively replace ozonation to treat high-alkalinity natural water and wastewater.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Comparison of isothiazolinone biocides degradation by O3 and O3/PMS in different water matrices
ce:section.ce:para: MIT and CMIT degradation by O3 and O3/PMS were compared in PBS, NOM, and secondary effluent (Fig. 9 ). The O3 and PMS dosages were used in PBS, NOM and secondary effluent, to compensate the increased complexity in water matrices, while the ratio of O3 to PMS dosage maintained as 2:1. In all water matrices, degradation efficiency was consistently high for O3/PMS, with the removal of more than 90% of MIT and more than 80% of CMIT, which suggested that the O3/PMS process showed good prospects application to resistant micropollutants degradation. In PBS, the synergy between O3 and PMS enhanced degradation efficiency, relatively to ozonation, by 30.7% and 62.5% for MIT and CMIT, respectively. The effect was more limited in the other water matrices, with an efficiency enhancement for CMIT of 5.0% in NOM and 11.6% in secondary effluent.

Dissolved organic matter (DOM) in NOM or secondary effluent are likely the dominant factor affecting isothiazolinone biocides degradation. First, electron-rich moieties in DOM (e.g., aniline and phenol), can initiate O3 to form OH, acting as initiator. Therefore, instantaneous oxidation of MIT and CMIT is important in NOM and secondary effluent (Flyunt et al., 2003; Tekle-Rottering et al., 2016). For example, O3 concentration in NOM decreased by 49% and 64% within 10 s during ozonation and O3/PMS, respectively, resulting in CMIT degradation efficiency of 70% and 82%, respectively (Fig. 9 and Fig. S6). Second, DOM can quench OH and
Image 1 rapidly, which are the main reactive oxygen species formed by the synergy between O3 and PMS, acting as inhibitor (Katsoyiannis et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2015). Third, the residual amount of O3 available to react with PMS is insufficient because of the high instantaneous O3 decay, thus radical formation decreases.

We studied the oxidation capacity and radical formation of the O3/PMS process for isothiazolinone biocides (MIT and CMIT) degradation. Synergistic effects of O3 and PMS accelerated MIT and CMIT degradation and increased degradation efficiency.

Compared with ozonation and O3/H2O2, the O3/PMS process shows some unique advantages. Firstly, OH and
Image 1 can be generated simultaneously with considerably high radical yields during the O3/PMS process. Molecule O3 is favorable toward O3-reactive degradation, while OH and
Image 1 are conducive to refractory micropollutants degradation. Secondly, the observed reaction rate between O3 with the deprotonated fractions of PMS is higher than that of O3 with the deprotonated fractions of H2O2 under the circumneutral condition, which is conducive to the effective O3 depletion of PMS. Thirdly, O3/PMS may show better adaption to the real wastewater due to the selectivity of
Image 1 to background organic constituents and direct activation of some inorganic anions on PMS, such as HCO3 −. Therefore, the O3/PMS process shows good prospects for application to micropollutants degradation in water and wastewater treatment.

Nevertheless, the presence of DOM in actual wastewater competes with the target micropollutants to depleting O3 and radicals, resulting in inhibition effect on the enhancement of O3/PMS. In order to reduce the negative effects of DOM and ensure that the synergistic process can give full play the role of resistant micropollutants degradation, the appropriate pretreatment technologies, can be added in the front of O3/PMS.

Although the O3/PMS process is an effective technology for the advanced treatment of reclaimed water, the effect on by-products formation should be further evaluated to determine its feasibility and safety in practical application, especially in the presence of halogen ions. What's more, the formation of intermediates and the change of toxicity in the treatment of toxic contaminants (such as MIT and CMIT) by O3/PMS should also be paid attention to.
